columns.text: The goal of this task is to rewrite the net present value of the merger in terms of the synergy and the merger premium.

First, let's remember ***What is the Merger Premium?***

The **Merger Premium** represents the amount paid above the stand-alone value of the target firm.

Let's use variables and formulas to illustrate this concept! 


Let, the firm $B$ be the target firm of the firm $A$.

So, the **Market Value** of the firm $B$ is represented by $V_B$.

The firm $A$ will make an offer to acquire firm $B$ and will calculate the **Cost of firm $\bold{B}$ to firm $\bold{A}$** $(\text{Cost}_B)$. 

Therefore, the **Merger Premium** can be represented by the following formula:

$$
\begin{equation}
\text{Merger Premium}=\text{Cost}_B-V_B
\end{equation}
$$

Now, from formula $(2)$ and $(3)$ we can show the **Net Present Value** as the **Market Value** of the target firm, the **Synergy** and the **Cost of firm $\bold{B}$ to firm $\bold{A}$**:

$$
\begin{align*}
\operatorname{NPV}&=V^{*}_{B} -\text{Cost}_B\\[10pt]
&=V_{B}+\Delta V-\text{Cost}_B\\[10pt]
&=\Delta V-(\text{Cost}_B+V_{B})\\[10pt]
\end{align*}
$$
Now, notice that formula $(1)$ can be used and we finally get the desired result:

$$\boxed{\operatorname{NPV}=\Delta V-\text{Merger Premium}}$$

Notice that we have used the definitions provided in this section of **Net Present Value** of the merger and also the definition of **Synergy**. The key point in this solution was the definition of **Merger Premium** as the amount paid above the stand-alone value of the target firm.
